page.title: 17Local History
page.content: Though there are a few place-names with Anglian elements the prevalence of Norse elements suggests that the major clearance and settlement of the area was an Irish-Scandinavian movement eastwards in the 9th to 11th centuries. The main E-W road is called "The Street" which might relate to a Roman presence, perhaps leading to the mineral rich areas on its southern border. The first recorded mining works date to the 16th century but were at their height during the 19th century. Old miners' cottages in Fellside are now joined to form larger dwellings. Water power was used for the bobbin mill in The Howk. Numerous quarries provided building stone for houses and barns. Derelict lime-kilns once produced lime to fertilize the fields. A house at Whelpo was once a Quaker meeting house and burial ground
